perturbation.original_text: MBE agrees to use its commercially reasonable efforts to execute agreements, or to facilitate the execution of agreements among the appropriate parties, so that such Basic Fee is paid to the Company directly from the carrier which ships such package no later than fifteen (15) days following the end of the month in which such package was shipped.
perturbation.changed_text: MBE agrees to use its commercially reasonable efforts to execute agreements, or to facilitate the execution of agreements among the appropriate parties, so that such Basic Fee is paid to the Company directly from the carrier which ships such package no later than sixty (60) days following the end of the month in which such package was shipped.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the payment deadline to sixty days, which could violate prompt payment laws in some states, requiring payment within a shorter timeframe, like 30 days.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Prompt Payment Laws (example: California Prompt Payment Act)

perturbation.original_text: The Company shall pay such amounts, less the relevant Bounty Fee or eBay Fee then in effect, to MBE on the next business day or as soon as reasonably practicable (but in any event within one week) following the shipment date of each package, and MBE agrees to distribute such amounts to the MBE Centers.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company shall pay such amounts, less the relevant Bounty Fee or eBay Fee then in effect, to MBE at the Company's discretion, and MBE agrees to distribute such amounts to the MBE Centers whenever it deems appropriate.
perturbation.explanation: By giving the company complete discretion over payment timing, this contradicts laws that require timely and predictable payment schedules. This is especially problematic since the agreement appears to relate to franchise operations, where payment schedules are crucial.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Franchise Laws and General Contract Law (Reasonable Time for Payment)

perturbation.original_text: Either party may, at its option, terminate this Agreement upon notice to the other party if (A) the other party materially fails to comply with any of the material terms and conditions of this Agreement and (B) if such default has not been cured within thirty (30) days (forty five (45) days if required by the nature of the breach) after written notice to the other party or, if such breach is not curable within thirty (30) days (forty five (45) days if required by the nature of the breach), reasonable efforts and progress are not being made to cure such breach.
perturbation.changed_text: Either party may, at its option, terminate this Agreement upon notice to the other party if the other party materially fails to comply with any of the material terms and conditions of this Agreement and such default has not been cured within ten (10) days after written notice to the other party, regardless of the nature of the breach.
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the cure period to a flat ten days for any material breach, which may be insufficient and unreasonable, especially for complex breaches. This could be deemed an unreasonable contract term and conflict with principles of good faith and fair dealing.
